awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: State Variation in Mass Incarceration Reforms
awd_abstract_narration:
After years of increasing incarceration in the United States, recently many states have passed reforms aimed at reducing their prison populations. However, not all states have embraced reform of their incarceration rates and policies. This project will examine what has led some states but not others to initiate new policies that could reduce rates of imprisonment. Consequently, this project takes advantage of the shift in national context and the new variation in state level reforms to assess how states create or impede significant reforms of their incarceration policies.

The project will examine legislative incarceration reform efforts in several states between 2000 and 2016. To do so, the project will use a paired case study comparison design. Three sets of state-pairs in different geographical regions will be matched on theoretically relevant variables known to correlate with penal policy and incarceration rates. The matched state-pairs design allows for variation in extent of reform. Data for the project will include archival and legislative documents, media content, and interviews. De-identified data from the project will be made publicly available. In this way, the project will help determine why some states have enacted incarceration reform, while others have been impeded in doing so. The project also will help identify effective strategies, resources, and processes with the most potential to better understand unnecessary incarceration within different state contexts.

por.por_cntn:
The project aims to identify state level criminal justice reforms that influence state correctional populations and to map the actors and organizations that have engaged in reform processes over time and across state contexts. The first goal is to use the data to generate new theories of penal change. The second goal is to better understand the actors, organizations and institutions that shape legal and policy changes in order to make clear which approaches are best suited to reduce state incarceration rates.  The project includes case studies of six match-paired states (New Jersey-Pennsylvania, Illinois-Michigan, and Florida-Georgia). Co-PIs plan to publish the findings in academic articles, general interest articles and a book.

 

The project is designed to help explain why the United States incarcerates far more people than other similar nations and why certain states continue to do so while others have sought to implement reforms that move away from mass imprisonment. A large body of research shows that mass imprisonment has at best a marginal positive effect.on public safety and that it imposes great costs that disproportionately affect historically marginalized populations, especially African Americans. Incarceration on this scale also comes at great fiscal cost, straining state budgets and diverting valuable resources that might be better deployed to address crime's causes. By providing in-depth accounts of the forces that shaped policies across six states, the project provides valuable insights that might help lawmakers and others pursue policy objectives that reduce the nation's reliance on imprisonment.  

 

Our preliminary findings suggest several promising directions to expand and improve on theories of penal change. For example, among those states that were among the earliest to implement decarceral reforms, correctional administrators who were forced to respond to tensions and problems created by ballooning prison populations and sharp spending increases played key roles in initiating reforms. Also, our findings suggest that legislation was less important than administrative changes intended to reduce prison populations until well after the great recession when reform legislative activity increased. The data also illustrate how states that passed the most impactful reforms were struggling with sharp budget deficits and were often experiencing changes in state partisan power. Lastly, the project has helped show how lawmakers respond to corruption and scandal in very different ways depending on the political costs that these problems are likely to impose. 

 

We expect our findings and products to contribute to knowledge and scholarship in several different ways. First, it makes an important contribution to our empirical base for studying penal change by creating a unique and accessible collection of data across six states over the twenty most recent years when correctional reforms gained momentum. Theoretically our data and findings should provide the tools to expand our understanding of how and why state trajectories differ and what specific causal mechanisms affect reform. Third, we invested considerable effort in designing protocols and incorporating innovative information technology tools to manage large volumes of qualitative data. This work should provide some useful insights for scholars aiming to manage diverse data across multiple sites. 

 

Lastly, it is well documented that mass incarceration has inflicted serious social harm and that these consequences disproportionately fall on the nation's poorest and most marginalized populations. Over-incarceration's fiscal costs have been enormous and its social costs have created generations of families for whom long prison terms have become a normal part of the life course. These costs have done little to reduce serious crime and have perpetuated historical injustices against Black and Hispanic populations. This project's biggest goal is to highlight how building and sustaining carceral responses to crime are the product of choices made by people in positions of power who have options beyond imprisonment. Mass incarceration is not the outcome of a singular policy goal or strategy. It is instead the product of many decisions over time that were made by many different people. Any path out of mass incarceration will require a similar process where actors make different choices, informed by mass incarceration's failures and injustices. This project aims to contribute to an informed path forward that might better utilize the nation's resources to address the causes of crime rather than respond in the punitive and brutal way that defined the latter 20th century.
